thread.title: Activists hope to draw 10,000 to Boulder march during GOP debate
thread.title_full: Activists hope to draw 10,000 to Boulder march during GOP debate - The Denver Post

author: Sarah Kuta
title: Activists hope to draw 10,000 to Boulder march during GOP debate
text:
Activists are hoping to draw 10,000 people from a variety of organizations and causes for a march on the same day as the Republican presidential debate at the University of Colorado this month.
The Oct. 28 demonstration, called "Our Future, Our Choice: March for Civic Engagement," begins at the Glen Huntington Bandshell in Boulder's Central Park and ends at the Coors Events Center, where Republican candidates will be sparring with each other during a live television broadcast.
The activists are planning to use CU's Business Field, which is across Regent Drive from the arena, for post-march activities and displays.
Gary Roland, who is helping to organize the march, said groups who are interested in topics such as climate change, health care, immigration, gender equality and education are likely to participate.
The interested groups have been asked to create an art piece that demonstrates their vision for the future, Roland said.
"The march is a demonstration of the future we're building and so rather than actually calling out the parties, we'll tell them 'The future we envision is this,'" he said. "We're inviting people to come out and express the future they want to see."
One group that plans to use the Republican debate to shine a spotlight on its movement is the fossil fuel divestment initiative at CU. That group was active last year on all of CU's campuses, including Boulder, where students held a three-day "camp out" demonstration last spring to urge the Board of Regents to divest from coal, oil and gas.
Advertisement The students, apparently undeterred by the regents' formal "no" vote on divestment last spring , have been holding regular meetings this fall.
"We are really excited about this opportunity because it is such a high-profile event," said P.D. Gantert, who is taking time off from his studies at CU to work on the divestment movement. "Opportunities like this are exciting because it allows everybody to come together and merge the vision that we have for change in the world."
Gantert said the march is not meant to be "antagonistic or aggressive," but rather, a peaceful and informative demonstration that organizers hope will encourage students to engage with the political process.
Mike Eubank, special events coordinator for the city of Boulder, said he is aware of the "march concept" but has not received formal notification from the group yet.
The city encourages groups to fill out an "advocacy application" for activities on public property that fall under the free speech protections of the U.S. Constitution.
Boulder police traffic and special events Cmdr. Greg LeFebre directed all questions about potential demonstrations to the CU-Boulder Police Department.
For its part, the university's police force is trying to coordinate with any groups or individuals who want to demonstrate outside the Coors Events Center.
Students who are calling on debate organizers to make more tickets available to them are also planning their own event and live broadcast from some to-be-determined campus location "to discuss the issues facing our generation and the nation," according to a resolution going before the CU Student Government.
CU has also been contacted about hosting a rally with several Colorado Democrats, though details are still being worked out, said CU police Sgt. Mike Lowry.
The Business Field has been designated as a "free speech zone" for all demonstrators, Lowry added.
"Certainly people are allowed to disagree, that's what makes this country great and we're going to try and do it in a safe manner so that everyone can be heard," Lowry said.
